ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I have developed an appreciation for multiple different perspectives and arguments through taking this course. Profess Syrimis encouraged wide thinking, and pushed us to develop arguments that we were less confident in.
This course was very Interesting. I gained a lot of insights regarding different fields in history, philosophy but also generally in life.
Connection between pas and present Olympics as well as all the different aspects to the Olympics.
I learned about education in Ancient Greece. I also learned about different contemporary historical events through the Olympic Games.
I developed knowledge of ancient Greece as well as contemplated the innate nature of sport to a deep degree.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths -- Professor Syrimis is incredibly passionate about sports and the Olympics, and this came across throughout the course. 
Weakness -- A lot of the course was premised on student engagement, and it would have been much more productive for conversations if students were more comfortable with speaking in class and voicing opinions. Sometimes there was a lack of organization, but much of this was because students were disorganized rather than the Professor.

strengths:
The course was very well taught. Every week had a certain goal, which was very interesting to learn
I thought the course was well organized and I enjoyed the material. I wish we had had a little more straight forward information about assignments but overall good.
I like that it's a small class. Conversations flow very easily. It's a great way to also meet people from different paths at Yale.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend it to a student who is interested in current controversies in sport, and wishes to think more widely about the implications of sport and the Olympics in the modern day. The focus on ancient history of the Olympics at the start of the course gives you an appreciation of the meaning of the Olympics and how it has changed and evolved over time, and whether current issues are straying from the original intentions of the competition or not. The mix of student athletes and students was complementary to the course, meaning multiple different perspectives were brought into consideration.
I will recommend this course to any student
Yes 100%! Great way to learn about History! It's a great course to take if you want a small class with lots of discussion.
Yes, its a interesting class with a lower workload.
